awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports participation in three meetings of the Troy MathFest conference series, taking place in Troy, AL in April of 2019, 2020, and 2021.  This is an undergraduate mathematics research conference that includes sessions for undergraduate presentations (although graduate students and faculty are welcome to present, too), a poster session, graduate school information session, a calculus competition, and two invited faculty speakers. The goals of the conference series are (1) to help participating students develop better scientific literacy and appreciation by learning new mathematical ideas; (2) to provide the participants experience in preparing and delivering a presentation; and (3) to help better prepare the next generation of mathematicians for graduate school and beyond. 

The Troy MathFest is an undergraduate research conference that includes presentations by students working in a wide range of areas of mathematics. The conference provides an environment where students from various academic institutions gather to build collaborations and learn new mathematics from one another.  The conference also provides the opportunity for students to attend keynote lectures from prominent mathematicians who have records of working with undergraduates on research.  The meeting further provides the opportunity for students to learn about regional mathematics graduate programs and to connect with their representatives.  The conference concludes with a competitive and compelling calculus competition, in which students can showcase their skills and possibly win prizes. More information can be found at the conference series web site:  https://www.troy.edu/mathfest/.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

TROY MathFest 2019-22 (originally set for 2019-21, but due to COVID-19, we did not hold the conference in 2020; we did have the conference in years 2019, 2021, and 2022) was an undergraduate mathematics conference series held on April 5-6, 2019, April 9-10, 2021 (virtually through Microsoft Teams), and April 8-9, 2022 at Troy University in Troy, Alabama.  This was our 13th ,14th, and 15th such conference.  The 12th iteration of a conference was also supported by the National Science Foundation's Conference Grants program.  Some of our previous conferences were supported, however, by the MAA NSF-RUMC (NSF Grant DMS-0846477) grant for regional undergraduate mathematics conferences and Pi Mu Epsilon conference grants.

Our conference's intellectual merits included providing a forum for primarily undergraduates (and some graduates) in mathematics to present their work on projects, an opportunity for all attendees to learn mathematics not otherwise known to them by attending presentations and connecting with the speakers, and to be exposed to prominent mathematicians in the invited lectures. 

Some of the broader impacts included the following:

  • For the undergraduate students attending the conference, by virtue of attending the presentations, they would have learned some mathematical ideas that are new to them. As a result, their scientific literacy and appreciation would have improved.
  • For the undergraduate students who gave a presentation in this conference, this would have given them the experience of preparing and delivering a presentation, which better prepares them for their future careers, regardless of whether it is in mathematics.  In this sense, it helped contribute to a better future workforce.
  • For those pursuing careers in mathematics, this would help in the preparation of some of the next generation of mathematicians, by giving them experiences which will benefit them for graduate school and beyond.

Below are some combined totals from our 2019, 2021, and 2022 conferences:

  • There was a combined total ( from 2019, 2021, 2022) of about 295 participants at our 3 conferences.  
  • A total of 44 different universities/colleges were represented over the three conferences.
  • The 2021 conference was held virtually through MIcrosoft Teams.  All others were held on campus at Troy University.
  • There were 76 undergraduate students who gave either a presentation or a poster ove the three conferences. 
  • There were a combined total of 6 invited lectures (2 per year) invited lectures by distinguised mathematicians who have a proven track record of research with undergraduate students.  They were Drs. Madhuri Mulakar (University of South Alabama) on "Development and Future of Data Science," David Leach (twice, from the University of West Georgia) on "Lights Out with Linear Algebra" and "Counting with Algebra:  Unleashing the Power of Power Series," Annalisa Crannell (Franklin and Marshall College) on "Drawing Conclusions from Drawing a Square," Scott Batson (Office of Naval Research) on "Innovating the Future Force," and Vitaly Voloshin (Troy University) on "History of the Most Famous Error in Graph Theory."   
  • There were a combined total of about 92 students who participated in our calculus competition.  
  • There was an average of about 8.3 representatives from graduate schools in mathematics and statistics per year (some came each year). Each of the representatives were present during a graduate school browse session that gives undergraduate students the opportunity to talk directly to them about their programs, ask questions, and obtain information.  
  • In 2021 and 2022, we started a new math trivia competition for all participants using Kahoot. The undergraduate students have noted this was a positive and enjoyable activity during our conference.   
  • The grant allowed us to provide lunch and refreshments to the attendees, pay for the invited speakers, and to provide some travel support for student speakers from other universities.

 

As this was an undergraduate mathematics conference where students do not typically have new results (it may be known to the mathematics community, but not to the student at the outset of the project) , we do not anticipate publishing the results. 

We do believe that this is an important endeavor to host this conference, so that we give undergraduate students in mathematics this opportunity for its intellectual merits and broader impacts as stated above.
